entry.title: Windenergy
entry.content:
Wind Energy

Wind Energy in the United States

The first electricity generating wind turbine in America was built by Charles Brush in 1888. It stood in Ohio at 60 feet table and was capable of generating 12kW of electricity.

Fast forward 92 years and the world's first wind farm was constructed in Crotched Mountain, New Hampshire. Built in 1992, the wind farm consisted of 20 wind turbines with a capacity of 30 kilowatts each.

Now there are over 50,000 wind turbines in the United States that can produce 90,000 megawatts in a year. This represents around 5% of the energy production in the country.

And tomorrow? WINDExchange believes the United States could produce 10,640,080MW.

Locations of Wind Turbines in the United States

The United States Geologic Survey has released a dataset containing the location of every turbine in the country. Plotting this information reveals what regions are best suited for producing wind energy.

This visualization shows us that a handful of regions contain the majority of wind turbines. Wind speeds must reach 6 miles per hour before electrical energy is produced. This makes the Great Plains ideal wind energy producers.

This can be further shown by plotting each state's output individually. Source: WINDExchange

Although it takes some years for Texas to take the lead, the state becomes the country's largest wind energy producer by a large margin. Additionally, many states do not meet the conditions to be high wind energy producers.

Wind Energy Production by State


For us to reach WINDExchange's goal of 10 million MegaWatts per year we have to multiply our current wind output by 10 times. This would mean having hundreds of thousands more turbines.

Overall, there is a trend of increasing turbine efficiency but it isn't large enough. There must be a breakthrough in turbine efficiency that brings the number of turbines required to a reasonable amount.

Total Production and Turbine Efficiency

One of the benefits of wind energy is that once the turbine is installed, the energy it produces is free. But nothing is truly free. One concern is the feelings of residents who live near turbines. Source: Berkeley Lab's National Survey of Attitudes of Wind Power Project Neighbors

For the most part, people do not have issues with living over a mile away from a turbine. However there is noticible discontent among residents who are within half a mile. As more turbines are built, and the trend towards larger turbines continues, this will became problematic for more people.

Attitudes Towards Wind Projects by Distance

WINDExchange's potential estimate of 10 million MegaWatts seems lofty. Without major improvements to turbine efficiency, there probably isn't even enough space to fit the necessary turbines.

Still, a lot of progress has been made since the first wind farms. We should be proud of the advances that allow for the level of production that exists today.

entry.title: The Bias-Variance Tradeoff
entry.content:
What is Bias?

Bias is how much the model predictions are off compared to the actual values. If the bias is low, the prediction was accurate. If the bias is high, the prediction was inaccurate.

What is Variance?

Variance is the spread of the predictions. If the variance is low, the model is making predictions that are close to each other. If the variance is high, the model is making predictions that are far apart.

The Tradeoff

The goal is to get a low bias and a low variance. That means the model is making accurate, consistent predictions. The bias can be decreased by increasing the variance. That means the model will predict more accurately if it is given more flexibility but that can be erratic. Variance can be decreased by incresing the bias. That means the model can predict more consistent values but they will be less accurate.

Application

This concept gives insight on overfitting. A high variance may not initially seem like an issue, after all, the model is predicting accurate values. However, this makes the model overly attached to the training data. Its important to minimize both the bias and variance.
entry.summary: A balancing act for making predictions

entry.title: Logistic Regression
entry.content:
What is Logistic Regression?

Logistic Regression is a classification technique that outputs a probability that an instance belongs to a class based on an observation or multiple observations. For example, the probability that its summer based on the number of cricket chirps.

The Math

The Logistic Regression model probability can be represented by the equation 1/(1+e^-(a + bX)). The variable a represents the intercept coefficient. It will yield the probability of Summer when there are no chirps. The variable b is the observation coefficient. It is how much we believe that the observation contributes to the outcome. Finally X is amount of the observation.

The Significance

Logistic Regression provides a relative quick and easy way to classify data. It can handle both quantitative and categorical predictors.

Further Reading

Gradient Descent is a technique used to calculate the best estimate for this model.

entry.title: Precision and Recall
entry.content:
Precision

What percentage of cases predicted to be positive are actually positive? This metric considers the accuracy of the model when it flags something. It is the ratio if True Postiives / (True Positives + False Positives)

Recall

What percentage of flag worthy cases were actually marked by the model? This metric considers the model's ability to correctly identify positive cases. It is the ratio of True Positives / (True Positives + False Negatives)

The Significance

These metrics are important because its possible to maintain a high raw accuracy without doing anything in certain cases. Imagine trying to detect meteors that only appear every hundred years. If the model simply said there was no meteor every night the accuracy and precision would be high. However, the recall would be terrible since it wouldn't declare meteors even if they were visible.

Application

These metrics can be used to calculate F1 Score

entry.title: Lexical Diversity
entry.content:
What is Lexical Diversity?

Lexical Diversity is the ratio between unique words and total number of words in a passage. This will yield a value between 0 and 1. The closer the value is to 1, the more diverse the passage is.

Highs and Lows

It's easy to achieve a high lexical diversity score when the passage analyzed is short. I think a mark of good writing is that most sentences score 1 on the lexical diversity score. That means there are no words that appear more than once in the same sentence. In contrast the sentence I think might just have the lowest lexical diversity score is the famous "Buffalo buffalo Buffalo buffalo buffalo buffalo Buffalo buffalo".

Maintaining full lexical diversity in longer passages is quite the challenge. Additionally, calculating the value for a long work would be quite tedious. Luckily we can use Python and the NLTK to help us.

Computing Lexical Diversity

There's only two values we need to calculate the lexical diversity: the number of unique words and the total number of words. After tokenizing the text to be analyzed, extracting these values is quite simple.

The number of unique words = len(set(tokens)). This works because sets do not contain duplicate values. The total number of words = len(tokens). Divide those two values and there you have it.
entry.summary: Quantifying the uniqueness of words in a passage

entry.title: 3 Types of Probability
entry.content:
Marginal Probability: P(A)

The probability that an event will occur. It is not conditioned by another event. That's really it.

Joint Probability: P(A ∩ B)

The probability that an event will occur AND another event will occur.

Conditional Probability: P(A | B)

The probability that an event will occur given that we already know a different event has occured. The probability that A will occur given that we've witnessed B occur is P(A ∩ B) / P(B). That's the joint probability / marginal probability of the event we already witnessed. In plain english its the probability of events A and B happening divided by the chance of B happening in general.

Application

These probabilities are the building blocks of Baye's Rule
entry.summary: Simple explanation for Marginal, Joint, and Conditional probability
